00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief Lambert Conformal Conic Projection
00020    *
00021    * Implementation taken from the report,
00022    * - J. P. Snyder,
00023    *   <a href="http://pubs.er.usgs.gov/usgspubs/pp/pp1395"> Map Projections: A
00024    *   Working Manual</a>, USGS Professional Paper 1395 (1987),
00025    *   pp. 107&ndash;109.
00026    *
00027    * This is a straightforward implementation of the equations in Snyder except
00028    * that Newton's method is used to invert the projection and that several of
00029    * the formulas are modified so that the projection correctly degenerates to
00030    * the Mercator projection or the polar sterographic projection.
00031    *
00032    * The ellipsoid parameters, the standard parallels, and the scale on the
00033    * standard parallels are set in the constructor.  If the standard parallels
00034    * are both at a single pole the projection becomes the polar stereographic
00035    * projection (compare with the PolarStereographic class).  If the standard
00036    * parallels are symmetric around equator, the projection becomes the
00037    * Mercator projection.  The central meridian (which is a trivial shift of
00038    * the longitude) is specified as the \e lon0 argument of the
00039    * LambertConformalConic::Forward and LambertConformalConic::Reverse
00040    * functions.  The latitude of origin is taken to be the latitude of tangency
00041    * which lies between the standard parallels which is given by
00042    * LambertConformalConic::OriginLatitude.  There is no provision in this
00043    * class for specifying a false easting or false northing or a different
00044    * latitude of origin.  However these are can be simply included by the
00045    * calling function.  For example the Pennsylvania South state coordinate
00046    * system (<a href="http://www.spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/3364/">
00047    * EPSG:3364</a>) is obtained by:
00048    \code
00049    const double
00050      a = GeographicLib::Constants::WGS84_a(), r = 298.257222101, // GRS80
00051      lat1 = 39 + 56/60.0, lat1 = 40 + 58/60.0, // standard parallels
00052      k1 = 1,                                   // scale
00053      lat0 = 39 + 20/60.0, lon0 = 75 + 45/60.0, // origin
00054      fe = 600000, fn = 0;                      // false easting and northing
00055    // Set up basic projection
00056    const GeographicLib::LambertConformalConic PASouth(a, r, lat1, lat2, k1);
00057    double x0, y0;
00058    {
00059      // Transform origin point
00060      PASouth.Forward(lon0, lat0, lon0, x0, y0);
00061      x0 -= fe; y0 -= fn;         // Combine result with false origin
00062    }
00063    double lat, lon, x, y;
00064    // Sample conversion from geodetic to PASouth grid
00065    std::cin >> lat >> lon;
00066    PASouth.Forward(lon0, lat, lon, x, y);
00067    x -= x0; y -= y0;
00068    std::cout << x << " " << y << "\n";
00069    // Sample conversion from PASouth grid to geodetic
00070    std::cin >> x >> y;
00071    x += x0; y += y0;
00072    PASouth.Reverse(lon0, x, y, lat, lon);
00073    std::cout << lat << " " << lon << "\n";
00074    \endcode
00075    **********************************************************************/
00076   class LambertConformalConic {
00077   private:
00078     typedef Math::real real;
00079     const real _a, _r, _f, _e2, _e, _e2m;
00080     real _sign, _n, _nc, _lt0, _t0n, _t0nm1, _scale, _lat0, _k0;
00081     static const real eps, eps2, epsx, tol, ahypover;
00082     static const int numit = 5;
00083     static inline real sq(real x) throw() { return x * x; }
00084     // e * atanh(e * x) = log( ((1 + e*x)/(1 - e*x))^(e/2) ) if f >= 0
00085     // - sqrt(-e2) * atan( sqrt(-e2) * x)                    if f < 0
00086     inline real eatanhe(real x) const throw() {
00087       return _f >= 0 ? _e * Math::atanh(_e * x) : - _e * std::atan(_e * x);
00088     }
00089     inline real mf(real sphi, real cphi) const throw() {
00090       return cphi/std::sqrt(1 - _e2 * sq(sphi)); // Snyder's m, p 108, eq 14-15
00091     }
00092     inline real tf(real sphi, real cphi) const throw() {
00093       // Snyder's t, p 108, eq 15-9a
00094       // First factor is sqrt((1 - sphi) / (1 + sphi))
00095       // Second factor is ((1 + e * sphi)/(1 - e * sphi)) ^ (e/2)
00096       return (sphi >= 0 ? cphi / (1 + sphi) : (1 - sphi) / cphi) *
00097         std::exp(eatanhe(sphi));
00098     }
00099     inline real logtf(real sphi, real cphi) const throw() {
00100       // Return log(t).  This retains relative accuracy near the equator where
00101       // t -> 1.  This is the negative of the standard Mercator northing.  Note
00102       // that log( sqrt((1 - sin(phi)) / (1 + sin(phi))) ) = -asinh(tan(phi))
00103       return -Math::asinh(sphi/std::max(epsx, cphi)) + eatanhe(sphi);
00104     }
00105     inline real logmtf(real sphi) const throw() {
00106       // Return log(m/t).  This allows the cancellation of cphi in m and t.
00107       return std::log((1 + sphi)/std::sqrt(1 - _e2 * sq(sphi))) -
00108         eatanhe(sphi);
00109     }
00110     void Init(real sphi1, real cphi1, real sphi2, real cphi2, real k1) throw();
00111   public:
00112 
00113     /**
00114      * Constructor with a single standard parallel.
00115      *
00116      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00117      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00118      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00119      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00120      * @param[in] stdlat standard parallel (degrees), the circle of tangency.
00121      * @param[in] k0 scale on standard parallel.
00122      *
00123      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat
00124      * is not in the range [-90, 90].
00125      **********************************************************************/
00126     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r, real stdlat, real k0);
00127 
00128     /**
00129      * Constructor with two standard parallels.
00130      *
00131      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00132      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00133      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00134      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00135      * @param[in] stdlat1 first standard parallel (degrees).
00136      * @param[in] stdlat2 second standard parallel (degrees).
00137      * @param[in] k1 scale on the standard parallels.
00138      *
00139      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat1
00140      * or \e stdlat2 is not in the range [-90, 90].  In addition, if either \e
00141      * stdlat1 or \e stdlat2 is a pole, then an exception is thrown if \e
00142      * stdlat1 is not equal \e stdlat2
00143      **********************************************************************/
00144     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r, real stdlat1, real stdlat2, real k1);
00145 
00146     /**
00147      * Constructor with two standard parallels specified by sines and cosines.
00148      *
00149      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00150      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e r = 0
00151      *   implies \e r = inf or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r
00152      *   indicates a prolate ellipsoid.
00153      * @param[in] sinlat1 sine of first standard parallel.
00154      * @param[in] coslat1 cosine of first standard parallel.
00155      * @param[in] sinlat2 sine of second standard parallel.
00156      * @param[in] coslat2 cosine of second standard parallel.
00157      * @param[in] k1 scale on the standard parallels.
00158      *
00159      * This allows parallels close to the poles to be specified accurately.
00160      **********************************************************************/
00161     LambertConformalConic(real a, real r,
00162                           real sinlat1, real coslat1,
00163                           real sinlat2, real coslat2,
00164                           real k1);
00165 
00166     /**
00167      * Set the scale for the projection.
00168      *
00169      * @param[in] lat (degrees).
00170      * @param[in] k scale at latitude \e lat (default 1).
00171      *
00172      * This allows a "latitude of true scale" to be specified.  An exception is
00173      * thrown if \e k is not positive.
00174      **********************************************************************/
00175     void SetScale(real lat, real k = real(1));
00176 
00177     /**
00178      * Forward projection, from geographic to Lambert conformal conic.
00179      *
00180      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00181      * @param[in] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00182      * @param[in] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00183      * @param[out] x easting of point (meters).
00184      * @param[out] y northing of point (meters).
00185      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00186      * @param[out] k scale of projection at point.
00187      *
00188      * The latitude origin is given by LambertConformalConic::LatitudeOrigin().
00189      * No false easting or northing is added and \e lat should be in the range
00190      * [-90, 90]; \e lon and \e lon0 should be in the range [-180, 360].  The
00191      * values of \e x and \e y returned for points which project to infinity
00192      * (i.e., one or both of the poles) will be large but finite.  The value of
00193      * \e k returned for the poles in infinite (unless \e lat equals the
00194      * latitude origin).
00195      **********************************************************************/
00196     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00197                  real& x, real& y, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00198 
00199     /**
00200      * Reverse projection, from Lambert conformal conic to geographic.
00201      *
00202      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00203      * @param[in] x easting of point (meters).
00204      * @param[in] y northing of point (meters).
00205      * @param[out] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00206      * @param[out] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00207      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00208      * @param[out] k scale of projection at point.
00209      *
00210      * The latitude origin is given by LambertConformalConic::LatitudeOrigin().
00211      * No false easting or northing is added.  \e lon0 should be in the range
00212      * [-180, 360].  The value of \e lon returned is in the range [-180, 180).
00213      **********************************************************************/
00214     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00215                  real& lat, real& lon, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00216 
00217     /**
00218      * LambertConformalConic::Forward without returning the convergence and
00219      * scale.
00220      **********************************************************************/
00221     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00222                  real& x, real& y) const throw() {
00223       real gamma, k;
00224       Forward(lon0, lat, lon, x, y, gamma, k);
00225     }
00226 
00227     /**
00228      * LambertConformalConic::Reverse without returning the convergence and
00229      * scale.
00230      **********************************************************************/
00231     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00232                  real& lat, real& lon) const throw() {
00233       real gamma, k;
00234       Reverse(lon0, x, y, lat, lon, gamma, k);
00235     }
00236 
00237     /** \name Inspector functions
00238      **********************************************************************/
00239     ///@{
00240     /**
00241      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00242      *   the value used in the constructor.
00243      **********************************************************************/
00244     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00245 
00246     /**
00247      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00248      *   value used in the constructor.  A value of 0 is returned for a sphere
00249      *   (infinite inverse flattening).
00250      **********************************************************************/
00251     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return _r; }
00252 
00253     /**
00254      * @return latitude of the origin for the projection (degrees).
00255      *
00256      * This is the latitude of minimum scale and equals the \e stdlat in the
00257      * 1-parallel constructor and lies between \e stdlat1 and \e stdlat2 in the
00258      * 2-parallel constructors.
00259      **********************************************************************/
00260     Math::real OriginLatitude() const throw() { return _lat0; }
00261 
00262     /**
00263      * @return central scale for the projection.  This is the scale on the
00264      *   latitude of origin..
00265      **********************************************************************/
00266     Math::real CentralScale() const throw() { return _k0; }
00267     ///@}
00268 
00269     /**
00270      * A global instantiation of LambertConformalConic with the WGS84 ellipsoid
00271      * and the UPS scale factor and \e stdlat = 0.  This degenerates to the
00272      * Mercator projection.
00273      **********************************************************************/
00274     const static LambertConformalConic Mercator;
00275   };
00276 
00277 } // namespace GeographicLib
